message: Corporates will be corporates after all. It is foolish to think of a profit seeking entity as the good guys, something I was guilty of at some point.
story: Ahmed Al-Amir shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: What Happens When You Talk About Salaries at Google
caption: wired.com
description: Former Google employee Erica Joy gave a tweet-by-tweet replay of exactly what happened when she tried.

data.message: At the same time, it's totally unpractical to ask any management to establish a utopia company. Any human-based system will have it's flaws. Only God's creation is bug-free.
let's see what you think when you have your own company.
Did not know we had Google shareholders in the group.

I believe the story has other sides as well. Please read Reddit & HN comments

https://www.reddit.com/r/technology/comments/3e05wg/what_happens_when_you_talk_about_salaries_at/
https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=9921335
That's interesting, did not know it was posted to reddit.

Good thing to get the other side of the story. I still insist on my original comment about corporates, there are no "good guys" there. In the case of Google for example, lots of people tend to think of them as some kind of a fairy that distributes free services.
i tend to beleive they are better than others.

Well, I agree with you from both the perspective of a developer and a consumer, they are definitely better than others. My point is that there is no such thing as a free lunch. They (and others) are not a charity.
exactly. and who ever say that is delusional. they are good as a company, it's a business afterall.

Of course they are a corporate & making money is their goal. However, her story has many holes. Why she's the only one who got punished? Why she didn't escalate the case - or even sue the company - it if it's illegal? Related to peer bonuses, you get them when you do something more than your assigned work goals, e.g. helping a colleague solve a bug. The sheet was nice, but it's not useful to the company. If I was her manager, I would reject the peer bonus as well (if it happened in the first place!)

Doing business is not evil. Nobody said that they are running the company for charity. And everybody does business for their own interest even Entrepreneurs and freelancers. But just because they are still small, nobody considers them as evil. But after all, we are all doing it for money.

I love what she did, and I was in the exact same situation one day at a company that has now become defunct (or close to it), the issue is that equal pay is a moral obligation, and what many people don't understand about capitalism and the market, is that employees have power in numbers too, I believe she could sue them if she gets the right lawyer (like an American Mortada Mansour  who can pull out enough CDs to get her a free salary for life :) ). Besides that, if Employees create a union like I've been asking for a long time, they would actually be able to shake down management into acting ethically. "Business" is not a synonym for "Immorality" :) , in a place where the rule of law is the case, the law should be fair and it should be applied. Every system will have a hole, in that case the management are obligated to take reasonable steps to accommodate, this is even done in public sector companies in Egypt btw :). Had this been a racial, gender issue, the PC vampires would have just shone their fangs and the management and they would have immediately complied :)
